p: Influenza vaccination is the most effective preventive measure [ 9] and the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) routinely recommends it for all persons 6 months and older. [ 10] Influenza vaccines continually demonstrate a great safety profile, [ 11] and though their effectiveness varies annually, in children they prevent doctor visits, [ 12] febrile illnesses, [ 13] hospitalizations, [ 14] and randomized trials show high pooled efficacy of the live, attenuated vaccine (83% relative reduction of influenza risk) for children <8 years old. [ 15] Moreover, there is building evidence that vaccinating children against influenza has benefits extending to other adults in the household (for example, by preventing work loss [ 16â€“ 20]). Influenza vaccines have been increasingly affordable and available to children through public programs [ 21] and because the Affordable Care Act requires new health plans to cover all routinely-recommended preventive services without cost-sharing.
